text:
Hi, if I have a model like (from tutorial)

@model function coinFlip(Y)
	p ~ Beta(1, 1)
	for n in 1:length(Y)
		Y[n] ~ Bernoulli(p)
	end
end

and want to compute the posterior likelihood given p=0.5 with coinFlip([true, true, true, false]). Is there a way to do this within Turing?

Thank you!

elements.text:

	p ~ Beta(1, 1)
	for n in 1:length(Y)
		Y[n] ~ Bernoulli(p)
	end
end

and want to compute the posterior likelihood given p=0.5 with coinFlip([true, true, true, false]). Is there a way to do this within Turing?

Thank you!

text: So we talked yesterday during the meeting about how my relatively simple model takes quite some time to run already (40+ minutes), and that I should post a snippet here to see if maybe there is a problem in the code, because I thought it might be normal given the 1800 samples and the model. There is quite a lot of missing data as well, but even when I just reran it with complete cases only, I still got above 40 minutes somehow anyway. I'll post a code snippet in the thread/comments.

There is quite a lot of missing data as well, but even when I just reran it with complete cases only, I still got above 40 minutes somehow anyway. I'll post a code snippet in the thread/comments.

text:
Hi folks, possibly non-Turing question here. I'm a newbie to Bayesian modeling and am working on learning the rudiments using a dataset of dogs in New York City.

I want to model the joint distribution of name and breed, and my raw data is (name, breed, count).

So far I've gotten as far as "learning" a Dirichlet posterior over dog breeds using a uniform Dirichlet prior and a multinomial likelihood (the observed counts).

I've been using a funny strategy of learning from e.g. all of the dogs NOT named Pugsley, then additionally learning from the Pugsleys and ranking breeds by the relative entropy between the prior and posterior, which surfaces those breeds for which learning that a name is Pugsley is most informative.

This feels like a bit of a hack, and what I'd really like is a model where I can ask about `p(name|pug)` and `p(breed|pugsley)`, which sounds like it would involve learning something about the joint distribution rather than going one variable at a time.

Not sure this is the best place to ask, but any suggestions or pointers to resources would be appreciated!

For fun, here are the breeds that are most likely when the dog name includes "snow":

elements.text:
Hi folks, possibly non-Turing question here. I'm a newbie to Bayesian modeling and am working on learning the rudiments using a dataset of dogs in New York City.

I want to model the joint distribution of name and breed, and my raw data is (name, breed, count).

So far I've gotten as far as "learning" a Dirichlet posterior over dog breeds using a uniform Dirichlet prior and a multinomial likelihood (the observed counts).

I've been using a funny strategy of learning from e.g. all of the dogs NOT named Pugsley, then additionally learning from the Pugsleys and ranking breeds by the relative entropy between the prior and posterior, which surfaces those breeds for which learning that a name is Pugsley is most informative.

This feels like a bit of a hack, and what I'd really like is a model where I can ask about
p(name|pug)
and
p(breed|pugsley)

, which sounds like it would involve learning something about the joint distribution rather than going one variable at a time.

Not sure this is the best place to ask, but any suggestions or pointers to resources would be appreciated!

text: If my Turing model has a positive variable `τ`, then `log(τ)` is what's actually being sampled. Is there a way given a `Chains` object and a `Model` to get all of the transformed samples (i.e. `log(τ)`)?

text:
So very recently we actually introduced an iterator interface to Turing.jl. This means that you can now do stuff like: <https://gist.github.com/torfjelde/cc5c41e97eb4c97e22a19b8440f6d506>

This gives you waaay more control over the sampling process, if you want it:) This is a very recent change though, hence it's not yet in the documentation (soon!).

text:
Some ongoing progress:

1. Refactor and improve particle MCMC and particle filtering samplers into a light-weight package `AdvancedPS` 
2. Unify and modularise some core tracing data structure in `DynamicPPL` and separate them into `AbstractPPL` <@UN45LV5K6> <@UCRDHV7PB> 
3. Implement an experimental sub-DSL that’s compatible with the BUGS modelling language, and add support for efficient generalised Gibbs sampling.  
4. Improve documentation and tutorials. 
5. Initial GPU accelerated HMC and RWMH support. 
6. Initial Annealed Important Sampling support and other model assessment methods. 
7. Initial Nested Sampling support. 
8. Revisit all Github existing issues, improve stability of public APIs and plan for Turing 1.0 release. 
9. any other issues raised by the Turing.jl and probabilistic programming community during the Turing.jl general public meeting and later feedbacks. 
We aim to keep this progress as transparent as possible. We’ll also try to minimise disruption to existing Turing.jl users by maximising backward compatibility.
We anticipate it might still be a long way ahead before we can release Turing 1.0. Any help, comments feedbacks on improving the development and release of Turing are welcome! We also welcome community developers to join the Turing.jl team. Together, we aim to make Julia the go-to language for Bayesian inference and computation.

root.text: Out of curiosity, what is the development plan for Turing over the next 6-12 months?

elements.text: Out of curiosity, what is the development plan for Turing over the next 6-12 months?
Some ongoing progress:
Refactor and improve particle MCMC and particle filtering samplers into a light-weight package
AdvancedPS
Unify and modularise some core tracing data structure in
DynamicPPL
and separate them into
AbstractPPL
Implement an experimental sub-DSL that’s compatible with the BUGS modelling language, and add support for efficient generalised Gibbs sampling.
Improve documentation and tutorials.
Initial GPU accelerated HMC and RWMH support.
Initial Annealed Important Sampling support and other model assessment methods.
Initial Nested Sampling support.
Revisit all Github existing issues, improve stability of public APIs and plan for Turing 1.0 release.
any other issues raised by the Turing.jl and probabilistic programming community during the Turing.jl general public meeting and later feedbacks.

We aim to keep this progress as transparent as possible. We’ll also try to minimise disruption to existing Turing.jl users by maximising backward compatibility.
We anticipate it might still be a long way ahead before we can release Turing 1.0. Any help, comments feedbacks on improving the development and release of Turing are welcome! We also welcome community developers to join the Turing.jl team. Together, we aim to make Julia the go-to language for Bayesian inference and computation.

To everyone,
We will have an open meeting on *18.12.2020 at 3pm CET*. If you have anything in mind that you like to discuss/ask (things that bother you, feature requests, …) or just want to hang out then fell free to join the video call. I’ll post the invite link in time in this channel.
